PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam Speaker (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 9 a.m., and read prayers.
Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill and five other related Bills is to enhance the capacity of the Australian dairy industry to market its produce. Measures are proposed to make the industry more market responsive. Government regulation of marketing is to be reduced. Assistance is to be provided in a less distortionary way, as recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission. Also provided for is reform of the Australian Dairy Corporation.

One year ago I introduced Bills into this House to reform dairy marketing arrangements. This House gave passage to those Bills; the Senate did not. Following the failure of the 1985 Bills to pass the Senate, the Australian Dairy Industry Conference sought Commonwealth Government support for its own plan which, while incorporating most of the features of the arrangements proposed in the 1985 Bills, also incorporated a production restraint device. The Government agreed to assist the implementation of this plan if it were shown to have broad industry and State Government support. Subsequently the Chairman of the Conference reported to me that there was insufficient support in the industry for this so called `ADIC plan' to proceed.

Last year I outlined the genesis and dimension of the problems facing the Australian dairy industry. I also demonstrated that the current assistance and marketing arrangements were inequitable and insufficient. These arrangements stimulate overproduction while discouraging domestic consumption; distort returns to individual manufacturers so that the Australian product mix is not the best; provide greatest assistance to exports to the least profitable markets, encourage imports and constrain industry unnecessarily by regulation. The passage of one year has not changed the nature or dimension of the problem nor the Government's concern to see the end to a system that is, demonstrably, serving the industry badly. Some reform has been able to be achieved within the framework of existing legislation, in particular the discontinuance of `allowances' on 1 July 1985. However, the need for thorough reform remains.

The Government's basic objective is the development of a more efficient and profitable dairy industry, able to respond as quickly as possible to changing market conditions and technology. Only through such industry development can we hope to maintain the largest Australian dairy industry that is viable at an acceptable level of industry assistance. The strategy to achieve this objective is directed both to the domestic market and the export market. In respect of the domestic market, the need is a system that encourages the local industry to improve its competitiveness so that it can maintain its dominance of this market. In regard to the export market, the strategy is to encourage the exploitation of the more profitable export markets, and in particular to discourage production for export that returns a net loss to Australia. This strategy is to be given effect by the following measures:

First, the cessation of export pooling arrangements so that exporters become more market responsive. A criticism that has oft been levelled at the current arrangements is that people are encouraged to play the system rather than to work the market.

Second, the replacement of current stabilisation arrangements, which provide an encouragement to the production and export of some dairy products more than others by arrangements designed to provide a more uniform level of assistance to all products. This change should, over time, encourage a more profitable mix of production.
Third, the market support arrangements which are to replace the current stabilisation arrangements will be financed in the least distortionary way, by a levy on all milk production.

Fourth, the progressive reduction in domestic price support to a level no higher than the price level at which New Zealand dairy products could be sold in Australia on a fair trade basis. Our industry must, over time, put itself in the position where it can defend its position in the Australian market on the basis of its competitiveness.

Fifth, the local industry will continue to be protected against unfair import competition. The industry has been able to achieve redress by invoking anti-dumping and countervailing measures where unfair competition has been shown to damage or to threaten damage to the industry. If, in the future, these measures should prove to be inadequate, other measures will be considered by the Government.

Sixth, the Australian Dairy Corporation is to be reformed to enhance its effectiveness, and to upgrade the accountability of the Corporation to the dairy industry. Seventh, assistance is being made available for specific purposes-for adjustment, for marketing innovation, for research, and for dairy underwriting.

Last year I announced that the Commonwealth would be prepared to participate with the States, on a one to one basis, in a joint $40m adjustment program for the dairy industry. Subsequently, the Commonwealth decided that, where a dairy specific program was undertaken within the rural adjustment scheme, the Commonwealth would contribute according to the general provisions of the rural adjustment scheme. This means that, for rural adjustment scheme special dairy assistance, the States are now required to match the Commonwealth dairy adjustment contribution only in respect of `carry-on' assistance. Arrangements covering dairy adjustment have now been finalised with most of the States.

On 15 April last, I announced the establishment of a $25m special fund for new marketing initiatives. The dairy industry is one industry that I would expect to take advantage of this fund. The dairy industry has advised the Government that the operative rate of research levy should be increased. Recently, Parliament increased the maximum rate specified by legislation, thus enabling an increase in the operative rate. The increased industry contribution on research will be matched by a similar increase in Commonwealth assistance for research. I will speak about underwriting later.

Let me now turn to the particulars of the Dairy Produce Bill 1986. This Bill provides the necessary elements of the arrangements to assist the marketing of dairy products. The Bill includes provisions to reform the Australian Dairy Corporation, to control the export of Australian dairy products, to enable the collection of levies for various purposes, to enable the making of market support payments, and to reform the Dairying Industry Stabilisation Fund.
Reform of the Australian Dairy Corporation

The Bill provides for significant reforms in relation to the Australian Dairy Corporation. These reforms stem principally from the Government's general program for reform of Commonwealth primary industry statutory marketing authorities and from the role the Corporation is to have in administration of the proposed new market support system. The reforms to the Australian Dairy Corporation proposed in this Bill have been decided on by the Government only after extensive consultation with industry representatives.
Objectives and Functions

The most basic plank of our policy on the reform of statutory marketing authorities is that the functions and objectives of each authority are to be clarified and clearly stated in its en- abling legislation. This Bill details the functions of the Australian Dairy Corporation, all of which involve an aspect of the marketing of Australian dairy produce. The objective to be given to the Corporation is that it should discharge these functions efficiently so as to enhance the profitable production and marketing of Australian dairy produce.

In a number of important areas the Corporation is to have significant discretion as to how it discharges its functions. These areas include, for example, the range of dairy produce to be assisted, the basis on which particular dairy products are to be assisted, and the availability of stock-holding finance from the Corporation. The proposed legislation requires the Corporation to make decisions in these matters having regard to its objective, and in some cases requires the Corporation to set down the criteria to be used to test whether a course of action would further the objective of the Corporation.
Accountability

As with other primary industry statutory marketing authorities, the Australian Dairy Corporation has dual accountability. One line is to the Parliament. The other line is to the dairy industry. The Commonwealth Government recognises the Australian Dairy Industry Conference as the industry organisation best able to speak for the Australian dairy industry as a whole, and the Council of that body as the appropriate organisation that should be consulted by the Corporation on the Corporation's activities generally. The Council of the Conference consists of representatives of dairy farmer organisations and representatives of dairy product manufacturing and trading organisations. The Conference has agreed to expand this membership to include a representative of the market milk sector and a representative of employees in the industry.

The proposed legislation will require the Council to be consulted by the Corporation when the Corporation is planning its strategy for the years ahead and when the Corporation is planning its operations for the forthcoming year. The Corporation will also need the approval of the Council if it wishes to undertake certain activities.

A significant degree of accountability to the industry will be achieved through the required interaction of the Corporation and the Council. To complement this, the annual report of the Corporation is to be presented to a meeting of the Conference at large and the Chairperson of the Corporation will report on the activities of the Corporation and answer questions arising. It may also be appropriate for the Chairman of the Council to report to the meeting of the Council's dealings with the Corporation, but that is a matter for the Council. It would be desirable for this meeting to be open to all persons involved in the Australian dairy industry.

The proposed legislation provides for accountability to the Parliament in the normal way through the tabling of an annual report. It should be noted that the legislation is to be tightened to require that the activities of any subsidiary companies that the Corporation may be permitted to form must fall within the functions given to the Corporation by the Parliament. In regard to Asia Dairy Industries, an already existing subsidiary of the Corporation, the Corporation will be required to ensure that the company undertakes only activities that are specifically allowed for by the legislation. It is also proposed that the Minister may in exceptional circumstances give directions to the Corporation. Where this is done, the directions are to be tabled in the Parliament within 15 sitting days unless there is a commercial or national interest reason why the direction should not be disclosed.
Powers

Subject to certain restrictions the Corporation is to be empowered to do all things that are necessary or convenient to be done in connection with the performance of its functions. In general, the Corporation will be subject to less ministerial control in operational matters than it is under current legislation. However this reduction is to be matched by new corporate and annual operational plan requirements and by the greater legislated interface between the Corporation and the Council of the Conference. I say legislated interface because much of what is in the proposed legislation is in fact occurring now without it being a legislative requirement.

There are to be two restrictions imposed on the power of the Corporation to deal in dairy produce. The first, which is in line with past practice, is that the Corporation's trading activities-in the broad-are to be approved by the Council of the Conference. The second is that council and ministerial approval is to be required where the Corporation wishes to engage in transactions that it anticipates will result in a loss. Loss-making sales involve a cross-subsidy from other dairy industry activities, and hence have the potential to thwart the objectives of the new marketing arrangements. Loss-making sales should not be absolutely ruled out because they may be necessary in exceptional circumstances. However they need to be controlled, and for this reason industry and ministerial approval is needed.

The Corporation will retain the power to make loans to assist manufacturers hold stocks of their dairy produce. Such loans have become a part of the dairy industry, allowing the farmer to be paid for his milk soon after its delivery.

The requirement for all loans to be secured will continue. The Government has been advised by the Corporation that one factor to influence the Corporation's decision on the rate at which loans can be made is the ability of the Corporation to meet any losses arising from a borrower's default should the security, on realisation, fail to cover the debt. As the reserves of the Corporation are relatively low the Government has decided to advise the Corporation that it should, until otherwise advised, determine loan rates on the basis that the Commonwealth would, if needed, be prepared to supplement the Corporation's reserves by up to $10m. There is no provision covering this in the Bills-an appropriation will be needed if ever this `guarantee' has to be called upon.
Corporate and Annual Operational Plans

The Corporation will be required to prepare and update each year a corporate plan covering three to five years ahead. The Corporation will also be required to prepare operational plans annually that are consistent with the corporate plan. The Council of the Conference is to be consulted during these processes. Both plans will require ministerial agreement.
Membership of the Corporation

The Government's policy is that statutory marketing authorities should be constituted on corporate lines and objective selection procedures used to seek out high calibre persons for appointment. The reasons for taking this approach, rather than an approach that constitutes statutory marketing authorities on the basis of industry sector representation, are given in the policy paper on Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities that I tabled in this House recently.

Consistent with this policy, the Bill proposes that the Australian Dairy Corporation should be restructured to include a Chairperson, a Government member, the Managing Director and eight other appointed members. Members in the last category are to be chosen by a selection committee that comprises a chairman who is selected by the Minister and four other members nominated by the Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference. The selection committee is given the task of selecting a board that collectively possesses a range of specified skills or experience.
Export Control

The Bill provides for kinds of dairy produce to be prescribed by regulation as controlled dairy exports. Export of controlled dairy produce will be permitted only by the Corporation or by licensed exporters. The regulations may prescribe conditions to be complied with in relation to the export from Australia of controlled dairy exports. Compliance with General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade-International Dairy Arrangement minimum prices will be made a condition of export. Under current arrangements export licences are issued by the Minister. This Bill provides for their issue by the Corporation. Criteria are provided for their issue, suspension or cancellation, and decisions are appealable.

The Bill provides that the Corporation may require licensees to consult the Corporation about their export intentions and performance. This provision will assist the Corporation in the discharge of its functions generally and may allow the Corporation to co-ordinate the activities of exporters to their individual and collective gain. It will also facilitate co-operation between the Australian and New Zealand dairy industries in third markets as provided for in the memorandum of understanding between the two industries pursuant to the Australian New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement.

I am aware of a concern expressed by some exporters that they may be commercially disadvantaged by being required to disclose to the Corporation their intentions in regard to specific market opportunities. To deal with this concern the legislation will require the Corporation to consider, in its planning process, the circumstances, if any, in which licensees will be required, in consultations with the Corporation, to disclosure details of intentions in relation to specific possible future export sales. Since this consideration will be part of the planning process the industry, through the Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference, will have to be consulted.

The Bill also provides for the Corporation to give directions to licensees in relation to matters specified in the Act or specified by regulation. However, the Corporation may not issue directions unless all licensees have been given 14 days notice and the Council of the Conference has agreed to the directions being given. Directions will need to be given by the Corporation if certain business, now exclusively handled by the Corporation with the agreement of the Conference, is to remain so.
Collection of Levies

This Bill provides for the collection of levies which are needed to finance the operations of the Corporation, including the market support and promotion arrangements, and to provide an industry contribution for research purposes. The proposed legislation follows existing legislation for the collection of research and promotion levies and stabilisation levies.

Provision has been made to allow the delayed collection of the market support levy. Delayed collection is possible because export of dairy produce will occur some time after the delivery of milk used in its production. Delayed collection may be desirable at the commencement of the market support arrangements in order to assist industry cash flow.
Financial Provisions

Part VII of the Bill deals with financial aspects of the ADC activities and updates current provisions having regard to the increase in autonomy that is to be accorded to the Corporation. A number of matters warrant brief mention. The means by which the Corporation can raise money are to be extended to include a wider range of contemporary financial instruments. A specific provision is made to enable the Corporation to engage in futures trading within appropriate guidelines. Investment in the short term money market of money which is temporarily surplus is provided for. To assist the better management of its moneys, the Corporation is to be empowered to make short term loans from one fund that it administers to another fund that it administers. Such loans may be made only to meet a temporary deficit in the receiving fund. A provision is included which requires the Corporation to credit any surplus and debit, any deficit, stemming from sales it makes in its own right, to the market support fund.

The legislation provides for the appointment of a commercial auditor in lieu of the Auditor-General. The appointment of a commercial auditor will require the agreement of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts. Part VII of the Bill also establishes four funds under which significant areas of Corporation activity are controlled and accounted. These funds are the Dairy Industry Fund, the Promotion Fund, the Market Support Fund and the Supplementary Market Support Fund.
The Industry Fund

The Industry Fund is to be established as the successor to the Dairy Industry Stabilisation Fund. The Dairying Industry Stabilisation Fund, or DISF as it is commonly known, is a long-standing fund administered by the Corporation. At 30 June 1985 the accumulated funds of the DISF amounted to about $5.5m of which $1.9m comprises the value of investments in various companies and $3.6m is in liquid assets.

Government policy has been that the moneys of the DISF are to be used for the benefit of the dairy industry at large. Accordingly the practice has evolved whereby, before any Ministerial approval is given to expenditure from the Fund, the Australian Dairy Industry Conference is consulted. The net effect of transforming the Dairying Industry Stabilisation Fund into the Dairy Industry Fund is to specify in legislation the purposes for which the fund may be used and to replace the requirement for ministerial approval with a requirement that expenditures from the Industry Fund be approved by the Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference. The Conference supports the approach that is being taken.
The Promotion Fund
The provisions in this Bill are essentially similar to those of current legislation
The Market Support Fund and the Supplementary Market Support Fund

The market support arrangements provided for in this Bill are proposed to apply to production on or after 1 July 1986. Central to the proposed new marketing arrangements are market support payments and supplementary market support payments. These are payments to be made by the Australian Dairy Corporation on export of all dairy produce. The making of such payments will improve the return on export and mean that a domestic sale would have to be made at a higher price than would otherwise be the case for the domestic sale to be as profitable as an export sale. In this way the system will provide support for the domestic price structure. The funds for the making of market support payments and supplementary market support payments will, apart from any Commonwealth contribution by way of underwriting, come from the industry.
The Market Support Fund

The Market Support Fund can be regarded as the continuing element of the new market support arrangements. Key transactions are the payment into the Fund of a market support levy, which is a levy raised on all milk produced, and the expenditure of Fund moneys as market support payments. Products eligible for market support payments are to be milk, cream, and dairy products declared for the purposes of the Act to be dairy produce by the Australian Dairy Corporation in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. The intention is that, subject to practical considerations, all products made from or containing milk or a constituent part of milk should be eligible for market support payments. The criteria adopted by the Corporation in deciding how far to go in declaring products to be dairy produce is to be stated in its corporate plan.

For each product that has been declared to be dairy produce the Australian Dairy Corporation will publish rates of market support payments and supplementary market support payment. Payment will then be made by the Corporation at these rates to the manufacturer of the dairy produce on presentation of proof that export has occurred. However, special rates will apply in certain circumstances and I will mention these shortly.

The rate at which market support payments will be made will be the rate ruling at the time of export unless another rate has been guaranteed by the Corporation. In this regard, the Bill provides that the Corporation may determine, on application by a person prior to export, that the market support rate for a particular export will be the rate ruling at the time of application rather than the time of export. This facility should assist exporters in making sales by providing them with a firmer basis on which to make an offer to a potential buyer than would otherwise be the case. Any decision of the Corporation not to guarantee a rate for a particular export will be reviewable under standard Administrative Appeals Tribunal procedures.

The Bill provides for the standard rate of market support payment to be determined in one of two ways depending whether the product is prescribed or not. For prescribed dairy produce, the rate will be determined as a percentage of the estimated average export price for the kind of dairy produce concerned. For other dairy produce, rates will be determined by the Corporation having regard to the rates established for prescribed dairy produce. The Bill provides for the Corporation to decide which kinds of dairy products should be prescribed dairy produce. The criteria adopted by the Corporation in this decision is to be stated in its corporate plan. Hence, industry will be consulted. Initially, it is expected that prescribed products will include those products which are now prescribed for stabilisation and export pooling purposes. For each kind of prescribed dairy produce the market support rate is to be 30 per cent of the estimated average export price, unless a different percentage is determined by the Corporation. This level of assistance has been accepted by the Government as a reasonable medium-term support level having regard to industry assistance considerations and the objective and strategy for the Australian dairy industry that I have already talked about.

It should be noted that the 30 per cent has been established in relation to estimates of average export prices under the export pooling system that has operated for many years. These estimates relate to a concept described as the `bulk ex-factory value', a concept that is designed to reflect the value added in the process of producing the dairy product but exclude the value added in packaging, transport, et cetera. It is anticipated that the Corporation will, initially at least, compile estimated average export prices under the new arrangements on this basis also. Should the Corporation consider that there is good reason to change radically the basis on which estimates of average export prices are to be compiled, the appropriate percentage to be applied in calculating market support rates would need to be considered by government. The Corporation will be required to reduce the percentage rate should it judge that a 30 per cent rate will not be able to be sustained, having regard to the funds likely to be available for market support purposes. The Corporation may reduce the rate for other reasons also provided that the Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference agrees with the reasons for wanting to do so.

Let me now briefly mention special rates of market support payment. These may be paid in certain circumstances. These circumstances include where a foreign country has imposed quantitative restrictions on exports from Australia and where necessary to conform with international trade commitments. Special rates may also apply to exports under agreements entered into before 25 February 1986 where the products concerned are sourced from production on or after 1 July 1986. The last mentioned provision is necessary so that agreements entered into before the announcement of the new arrangements are not disadvantaged.

Special rates of market support payment may also apply for underwritten products. Underwritten products will be the products that have been traditionally underwritten-that is, butter, cheese, whole milk powder, skim milk powder and casein. The market support arrangements for these products will work on a `pot holing' principle. When the export price falls below a specified figure the amount of market support payment will be increased above the level that would be calculated using the 30 per cent rule. More specifically, `pot holing' will apply when the estimated average export price for any of the underwritten products is below 85 per cent of what would be expected if export prices for the product concerned were on their longer term trend line. Where this `pot holing' is to apply, the market support rate will equal the difference between 110 per cent of the longer term trend value and the estimated average export price. Funds for `pot holing' will be drawn from the market support fund.
Supplementary Market Support Payments

The legislation provides for supplementary market support payments to assist the transition from current arrangements. Supplementary market support payments will be made whenever a market support payment is made. As with market support payments, supplementary market supports payments for prescribed dairy produce will normally be determined as a percentage of the estimated average export price of the product concerned, with the percentage being the same for all products. Special rates of supplementary market support may also apply in certain circumstances. Supplementary market support rates will decline over time as the product levies which provide their funding are reduced.

Initial rates of product levy and supplementary market support payment will be determined in line with a recommendation from the Australian Dairy Corporation that the theoretical domestic price support values under the new arrangements on 1 July 1986 should slightly exceed the theoretical domestic price support values, referred to as the DVLP-the domestic value for levy purposes-under current arrangements. The recommended increases are 5 per cent in the case of butter and 8 per cent in the case of cheese. The Government has accepted this recommendation in order to assist a smooth transition from current to new arrangements.
Underwriting

The Commonwealth will continue to underwrite average export returns for the traditionally underwritten products-butter, cheddar-type cheese, skim milk powder, whole milk powder and casein. Currently, underwriting applies in relation to the average export price received in respect of a year's production. The underwritten price is 90 per cent of the estimated average export price received for production of the most recent three years including the year in question.

A somewhat different basis for underwriting will apply in the future. The average export price received in respect of a year's sales will be underwritten. The underwritten price will be 85 per cent of the value that the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimates would have been obtained for the year in question if export prices were on their longer term trend line.

The change in the basis for underwriting has been made for a number of reasons. The new method will align better with the proposed new market support system, in particular with its orientation towards sales rather than production, and with its `pot holding' element. It also remedies a difficulty with the 90 per cent three-year-moving-average' approach; namely, that underwriting can be triggered when prices are declining but still relatively good in absolute terms, but may not be triggered during a progressive decline into a price trough.

The new basis also makes sense against the current outlook for international trade prices of an extended downturn before restoration of more normal price levels. The change in the basis of underwriting is expected to work to the benefit of the Australian dairy industry.
Financial Impact

The impact of these Bills on net Government expenditure is expected to be minimal. The Australian Dairy Corporation will reimburse the Commonwealth the cost of collecting the new market support levies. The cost of collecting all other levies will be met by the Commonwealth as it is under current arrangements. Appropriation of moneys for underwriting purposes is not provided for in these Bills.
Other Matters

There are two other aspects that I would draw to the House's attention. The first is the `sunset' clause providing for cessation of the market support arrangements after six years. Further legislation would thus be required for the arrangements to continue beyond June 1992.

One other aspect is a new provision concerning the liability of the Corporation for Asia Dairy Industries or any prescribed subsidiary companies. This provision makes the Corporation liable to meet any liabilities of ADI and any prescribed subsidiary that cannot be met from the subsidiary's assets in the event that the subsidiary is wound up. Should the Corporation ever be in this position, the cost of meeting the subsidiary's undischarged liabilities would become a charge against the moneys of the Corporation and could be expected to require a higher rate of Corporation levy than would otherwise be the case. The Australian Dairy Industry Conference has accepted this as a reasonable proposition in relation to Asia Dairy Industries. No prescription of any other existing company in which the Corporation has a shareholding is proposed.
Future Development and Review

I have already noted that the Australian Dairy Corporation is to have considerable discretion in the management of the market support system. This will allow the system to develop further in the light of the experience gained in its operation. The planning process will ensure that industry is consulted and ultimate Government control will be maintained. The Government will monitor the development of the system carefully and proposes to undertake, with the Corporation and the industry, major reviews in 1988-89 and 1991-92. I commend the Bill to honourable members. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Blunt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill and the complementary Dairy Produce Levy (No. 2) Bill is to impose various levies. These levies are required to finance the operations of the Australian Dairy Corporation including its activities in promoting dairy produce, to finance new market support arrangements and to raise moneys from the dairy industry for dairy research. The Bill imposes two types of levies-levies on milk fat produced on or after 1 July 1986 and levies on certain types of dairy products produced on or after 1 July 1986.
Levies on Milk Fat

There are four milk fat levies-the Corporation levy, the promotion levy, the research levy and the market support levy. The Corporation levy, the promotion levy and the research levy are to replace levies for similar purposes which are currently imposed on milk and butterfat under the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Act 1972.

Under the new levy arrangements, the amount of levy payable by a producer will depend on the amount of milk fat contained in his milk. Under current arrangements where a producer delivers whole milk to a processor, the levy is calculated at a rate per litre regardless of fat content; only where the producer delivers cream is the levy based on fat content. The change to a standard milk fat basis arises from a decision to base the market support levy on milk fat and the desirability of having a standard base for all levies on milk. The Bill provides a clause to cover the situation where it has not been possible to ascertain the milk fat content. This clause should only have to be resorted to for a small proportion of Australian production since most milk payment systems require the recording of milk fat content.

The Bill specifies maximum rates for all milk fat levies with the operative rates to be set by regulation. For market support levy the maximum rate of levy is to be 45c per kilogram of milk fat, which is equivalent to 2c per litre for milk of average fat content. In the case of the research levy, the maximum rate specified corresponds to the maximum rate of 2.5c recently set in the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Amendment Act 1986. The maximum rates for the promotion and corporation levies are respectively 5.5c per kilogram fat and 2.5c per kilogram fat.

In prescribing operative rates of levy, regard will be had to any recommendations by the Executive Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference. The market support levy is to be imposed in order to provide funds for the making of market support payments. These payments have the effect of supporting the domestic price structure for exportable dairy products at a level higher than would otherwise prevail. As a consequence, manufacturers of exportable dairy produce are able to pay a higher price for their milk than would otherwise be the case. This tends to establish a base price for milk with premiums above this price being established in particular uses. As market support payments thus underpin the entire structure of milk prices, it is equitable that the market support levy apply across all milk production.

However, a particular concern of some States is the possible impact of the market support levy on market milk producers if it were being imposed at a time of significant disruption or change in that sector. To address this and other concerns about the impact of the market support levy, the legislation provides for the possibility of a suspension of the levy and hence market support payments.

Any State Minister with portfolio responsibility for the dairy industry may notify the Commonwealth Minister for Primary Industry that the levy should be suspended. In the event of such notification, urgent advice will be sought on this matter from the Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference. This advice is to be received by the Australian Agricultural Council, considered, and a decision taken within 60 days of the notification being received by the Commonwealth Minister. At the expiration of the 60 days, unless the Australian Agricultural Council, by majority decision, has resolved that the levy should not be suspended, the levy is to be suspended as soon as practicable.

The market support levy is to be imposed on milk fat. This is, in part, because overseas experience shows that levy avoidance through `de-watering' of milk could be a significant problem if the levy were cast in per litre terms. It also makes sense in that the rate of payment to the producer for his milk generally varies in direct proportion to the milk fat content. The operative rate of market support levy will need to be a rate sufficient to finance the operation of the market support payments system. In prescribing a rate, regard will be had to any recommendation from the Australian Dairy Corporation.
Dairy Products Levy

Levies on certain dairy products are required to finance supplementary market support payments. Effectively, this levy will be imposed only on domestic sales of the product concerned. Levies will not be imposed on other than those products which are currently subject to stabilisation levies, and within this group only for products where a levy is considered necessary at the start of the new arrangements to support the domestic price for the product concerned. On current estimates of likely export returns, a levy will be required only for butter, butteroil and cheddar-type cheese. For butter, the levy required is likely to be of the order of $600 to $700 per tonne, for cheese $250 to $300 per tonne.

The levies imposed on dairy products are to be reduced over time. Levies imposed on 1 July 1986 will be maintained at their initial value throughout 1986-87 and then reduced in six- monthly steps. The first reduction will occur on 1 July 1987. The intention is that all levies other than on butter and butteroil should be eliminated by 1 July 1989, and that the rate of levy for butter and butteroil should be halved by then. The future of the levies on butter and butteroil is to be reviewed in 1988-89. Levies will be set by regulation. Levies on dairy products imposed by this Bill will apply to production on or after 1 July 1986. Stabilisation levies will not apply to production after 30 June 1986. I commend the Bill to honourable members. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Cadman) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to complement the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Bill by imposing certain levies on the import of dairy produce that has been exported from Australia and subsequently imported back into Australia. The Bill is necessary to close off an opportunity to exploit the market support arrangements that would otherwise be possible through an export/re-import procedure. Two levies are imposed. The levy on exempted dairy products is designed to re-impose a levy in respect of which an exemption was given on export of the product. The levy on supported dairy product is designed to avoid re-imports of Australian dairy products from obtaining the benefit of the market support payments made on export as well as the supported domestic price. Levy is payable by the importer. I commend the Bill to honourable members, and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Cadman) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRYING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND PROMOTION LEVY (TERMINATION OF LEVY) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Dairy Industry Legislation

The Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Act 1972 imposes levies on whole milk or butterfat produced in Australia and sold by the producer of the whole milk. These levies are used to fund the general expenses and the promotional activities of the Australian Dairy Corporation and to assist dairy research. The Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Bill provides for new levies to raise the funds for these purposes. These new levies will apply to milk fat produced on or after 1 July 1986. The purpose of this Bill is to limit the imposition of the old levies to production occuring before 1 July 1986. I commend the Bill to honourable members, and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Cadman) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY INDUSTRY STABILISATION LEVY (TERMINATION OF LEVY) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill now be read a second time.

Stabilisation levy is imposed on the production of prescribed dairy products. It is proposed that stabilisation arrangements should cease to apply at the end of the current production season on 30 June 1986. The purpose of this Bill is to limit the imposition of stabilisation levy to production occurring on or before 30 June 1986. I commend the Bill to honourable members, and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Cadman) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY LEGISLATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is one of six Bills, whose purpose is to establish new market support arrangements for the Australian dairy industry. Apart from clause 10, all provisions of the Bill are in the nature of transitional or amending provisions consequent upon the enactment of the proposed Dairy Produce Act 1986 and the other related legislation. Clause 10 is necessary to correct a typographical error in the Dairy Produce Act 1924 that came about when amendments were made to the Act in 1978. This error has been detected only recently and the Act has been administered over the years as it was intended to operate. The effect of the error is to make nonsense of the sub-section of the Act that enables advance payments to be made from the dairy produce export pools. Honourable members will note that the Bill provides that the amendment shall be deemed to have taken effect on 1 July 1978.

The Bill provides for the repeal of the Dairy Produce Act 1924, as amended, and the Dairy Produce Sales Promotion Act 1958, as amended. These Acts govern the operation of the Australian Dairy Corporation whose future operation is to be governed by the proposed Dairy Produce Act 1986. The Dairy Produce Act 1924 also provides for export pooling, which it is proposed should be terminated at the end of the current production season on 30 June 1986. The Bill provides for the continuation of those provisions necessary to allow the finalisation of current export pools in the normal way. The Bill provides for the repeal of the Dairy Industry Assistance Act 1977 and the Dairy Industry Levy Act 1977. These Acts, which deal essentially with market milk, have never been operative.

The proposed Dairy Produce Act 1986 will provide for the membership of the Australian Dairy Corporation to be reconstituted. It will not be possible for this to be done on 1 July 1986. Consequently this Bill allows for the members of the Corporation who hold office on 30 June 1986 to continue in office until the membership of the Corporation is reconstituted. This is likely to occur on 1 October 1986.

The Bill also provides for current export licences, which are due to expire on 30 June 1986, to continue in force until 30 September 1986. The Australian Dairy Corporation will issue an advice on how licences may be renewed or a new licence issued well before 30 September 1986. The Bill provides a number of other transitional or consequential measures that should be self-explanatory. I commend the Bill to honourable members. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Cadman) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:

In relation to the proceedings of the following Bills, so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the House making one declaration of urgency and moving one motion for the allotment of time in respect of all the following Bills:
Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986;
Taxation (Interest on Underpayments) Bill 1986;
Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986;
Fringe Benefits Tax Bill 1986;
Fringe Benefits (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill 1986, and
Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has had concerns about the extent to which the guillotine will be applied in this matter. We are most worried about the way in which the tax changes have been delayed. Every Australian knows that the measures are to take effect as from 20 September 1985. The debate today, covering essentially the negative gearing aspect, and the debate tomorrow, which covers the fringe benefit aspect with all its repercussions, are fundamental at this time of rather uncertain profitability in so many sectors of the Australian economy. We are very concerned that a guillotine will preclude certainly a proper analysis in this House of the Bills in Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: On other occasions a device has been used enabling committees of this House to sit and deliberate on the more controversial aspects of Bills outside this plenary session of the House. It could well be that such a device would have been more suited to the debate today. However, not only do we now face a guillotine that will ensure that all members of this expanded Parliament are to be denied a proper time and opportunity to speak on the legislation but it is almost certain there will be negligible debate, if any, in Committee. The Opposition has at least one amendment it wishes to propose. It is likely that it will not even be canvassed, unless we are given leave.

The result is that this House loses its capability to debate matters of this consequence and inevitably it will be the Senate that will take a great deal of time examining the issues, it is in the Senate that this Committee debate will take place and where probably a committee will be constituted to examine these matters further. We know that this is not the package that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) wanted. We know that prior to the National Taxation Summit he roundly castigated elements of the package. We know that he has expressed concern about the consequences for the economy in some elements of the package. Yet we are told that this House will not be given sufficient opportunity to debate the legislation adequately or to consider the detail of the clauses in Committee. The House is dealing with not just one Bill but an aggregation of Bills. The Bills are extremely important to continued investment opportunities in the community, and for that reason the Opposition feels that there should be adequate debate.

I know that the Leader of the House (Mr Young) has commenced proceedings this morning an hour earlier and that he intends to do so tomorrow. He believes that he has tried to accommodate members' interests. To a degree that may be so, but there is an expanded Parliament, the numbers in this place have been increased and the opportunities for members participating in debate have been reduced. Indeed, on the Government's side there is already an automatic requirement that no member in a second reading debate shall speak for more than 10 minutes. I do not know that it is necessarily a good thing for democracy that there are arbitrary time limits on debates. We have accepted it in this place as a convenience to give all members a roughly equivalent opportunity. But this guillotine and the nature of the consequence of this legislation and that which we shall debate tomorrow are such that I put to the Government that what is happening is an acceleration of the reduction of the significance of the House of Representatives. Yet the Australian Labor Party in its policy still suggests that there should be only a House of Representatives. If there were to be a House of Representatives alone and no Senate, inevitably the result would be to transfer even more power to the Executive.

If we look at the guillotine motion and the consequences of the debate today, we are seeing that Labor in government seeks not to preserve government by the elected representatives of the people but by those who are the elected representatives of Caucus. This measure is part of a subtle and sinister transfer of power from the people of Australia and those elected on their behalf to those who for the time being are the Government. While the Labor Party is in office one needs to be apprehensive at the way that applies in motions of such genuine concern to every man, woman and child in this country. On that basis we believe the guillotine to be inappropriate. Its consequence will be to deny proper debating opportunity on matters of major moment. Therefore, we shall oppose the motion.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Young's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Leader of the House (Mr Young) needs to understand that neither the Senate nor the Opposition are here to make the Government have an easy ride on matters that are against the public interest. The fact that the Leader of the House suggests that we have two days in which to debate matters which are of fundamental importance, and which are now nine months late is absolutely no excuse for there being a guillotine at all. If the Government were pursuing its responsibilities in a correct fashion, these measures would have been introduced last October. Notice was given last September that these measures, none of which have been made known to the community of Australia, were to commence from 20 September last. For the Government to have the hide to introduce them last week and to expect them to be debated in this chamber entirely in the course of two days is grossly unsatisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: No matter how much the Leader of the House might carry on, the reality is that it is not the dictates of the Senate that are applying the discipline as far as the passage of this Bill and the guillotine are concerned; it is purely and simply the inadequacies of the Government and the bungling and ineptness of a group of people who are unable to get their act together.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:TAXATION (INTEREST ON UNDERPAYMENTS) BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Mr Hurford:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill concurrently with the Taxation (Interest on Underpayments) Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering today the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986 and the Taxation (Interest on Underpayments) Bill 1986. The first Bill contains two major elements from the tax package of last year which were announced on 17 July in advance of the main statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 September. I refer to the negative gearing of rental property investments and a provision for depreciation on residential income-producing buildings. There is one other major item in the main Bill, and that is a system of self-assessment of taxation. There is one lesser, but still very important, item-the deductibility of donations to the Sports Aid Foundation-and there are three other relatively minor items with which the Opposition will have no quarrel. These include an amendment to overcome a decision of the Federal Court of Australia that sanctioned arrangements under which future income rights could be disposed of for a non-taxable capital sum. They also introduce grouping provisions into the Australian Capital Territory payroll tax law to close a loophole which enables employers, by payroll tax splitting, to make multiple use of the exemptions available for small payrolls. The Opposition will not oppose that.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a provision to give the force of law in Australia to an airline profits agreement with the People's Republic of China. I shall deal with those three items. We are not opposing them. The second Bill, the Taxation (Interest on Underpayments) Bill, formally imposes interest charges which are referred to in the first Bill, in order to meet the requirements of the Constitution.

I shall summarise the attitude of the Opposition to these Bills. Firstly, with regard to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986, the Opposition will be opposing negative gearing provisions. The Opposition will support the depreciation allowance of 4 per cent per annum on residential income-producing buildings. We support the taxing assignments of rights to future income and the grouping provisions for Australian Capital Territory payroll tax laws. We have grave concerns about the self-assessment provisions. We will not move amendments to the self-assessment provisions within the House of Representatives, but, in the Senate, we will move to refer the Bill to a committee so that the full implications of the self-assessment provisions can be examined in the necessary depth. In the course of my speech, I will give an indication as to why we believe that should be done.

We support the provisions regarding the airline agreement with China. With regard to the question of gifts to the Australian Sports Aid Foundation being made tax deductible, we will not oppose that measure, but my colleague the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), who is shadow Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, will indicate to the House some serious reservations we have about the operation of that proposal. My colleague will also move an amendment to the relevant clause of the Bill during the Committee stage of the debate.

This morning, in the Bulletin, it was indicated that a poll taken recently showed that the Government was now lagging behind the Opposition in the opinion of the Australian electors. According to the Bulletin poll, if an election were held now this Government would be thrown out of office. That is what the news was this morning. It is not surprising because, quite clearly, over the course of this year we have had the imposition of the highest rates in Australia's history since the Great Depression. That has had a very severe impact on families, farms, and businesses. People do not like it and they are indicating in the polls that they do not like it. We have had ministerial scandals, with the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) being involved in the most extraordinary shenanigans. People have noticed that and they do not like it.

Currently-this is after those polls were taken-we are in a state of total chaos and confusion because of the Government's failure to handle its constitutional responsibilities with regard to the Mr Justice Murphy affair. It is little wonder that the polls are showing that this Government would lose an election if it were held now. If the Government thinks that that is a good poll or that it is not too bad a poll, it is not taking into account the present state of confusion. With regard to what will be the subject of debate in this House today and tomorrow-that is, taxation-the major issue of taxation is yet to bite. Indeed, the biggest bite is ahead in the case of the major issue of interest rates. Therefore, if the Government thinks that today's poll is not too bad, that poll will look like a school picnic compared with what will happen in succeeding weeks and months.

This Government is now running into a very serious stage of disintegration in public support and in its decision-making processes. Nearly eight months after the statement made last September by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and nearly 10 months after the Treasurer's July statement relating to negative gearing these Bills are finally before the House for discussion. Over the whole of that period of 10 months in the case of negative gearing and of eight months in the case of all the other major provisions proposed in the 19 September statement, we have had confusion and uncertainty. The ordinary taxpayers and investors have been unable to decide what their true tax liability is. The incalculable effect on business confidence and on personal investor confidence cannot be underestimated. The Government simply does not understand what it is doing to the fabric of the economy through its taxation measures. When the Government sends out its booklet on fringe benefits tax, which was published the other day to every business in Australia there will be a storm of protest and concern at the extent of that single measure alone.

We have been told that because the Opposition has objected to some of these proposals quite properly on behalf of the Australian people, the Government may not introduce the income tax cuts that were mentioned in the statement of 19 September. I make it absolutely clear that the Opposition will not be bullied on this matter. There is no way in which we will fail to oppose bad measures just because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer wish to indulge in a certain amount of blackmail. The attitude of the Government is like that of a drug addict asking a bystander to help him rob the chemist shop. That is precisely what we are being asked to do. We are being asked to vote for thoroughly bad and damaging measures in order to assist the Government to meet taxation promises which possibly it should not have made in the first place. We simply will not be involved in that exercise; we are not prepared to help the Government rob the chemist shop; we will certainly examine each piece of this legislation to see what damaging effect it has on the Australian people; we will not be bullied.

These taxation measures go quite against one of the principal criteria suggested at the Taxation Summit by the Prime Minister-that is, that the proposals should be simple and clearly understood. That was one of the nine great principles which the Prime Minister declared in this chamber during the Taxation Summit. That principle has been breached absolutely. It is another broken promise by the Hawke Government. Before all these tax measures were introduced the Income Tax Assessment Act comprised about 1,100 pages. One may well say that that is far too many. The Opposition would agree with that. Since then the Taxation Laws Amendment (No. 2) Act 1985 has added 56 extra pages, Taxation Laws Amendment (No. 3) Act 1985 has added 53, Taxation Laws Amendment (No. 4) Act 1985-the notorious entertainment provisions-has added 55, the negative gearing provisions in this Bill add another 47 pages and the fringe benefits tax legislation which will come before the House tomorrow consists of 139 pages. That gives some indication of the deadly effect that that little booklet will have when it goes to every business house in Australia in the next three or four weeks. That means an increase of 350 pages in the Income Tax Assessment Act since we began this exercise. There will be an increase from 1,100 pages to 1,450 pages-a 32 per cent increase in the size and complexity of that Act. So much for the Prime Minister's criterion of simplicity and so much for his promise that we would have genuine tax reform.

I must also draw to the attention of honour- able members another example of the sheer contempt and arrogance that the Government shows to the House of Representatives and the Senate and therefore to the Australian people. I refer initially to the requests by my colleague the shadow Minister for taxation and finance, Senator Messner, to the Treasurer, Mr Keating, for a briefing on the Bill that we are discussing today. I do not know whether honourable members or members of the public understand this, but it is a fairly normal practice for departmental officers to be made available to the Opposition or to private members wishing to exercise their proper responsibility on behalf of the Australian people. It is quite a normal procedure to ask the relevant Minister for a briefing by officials. It is up to the Minister to indicate the extent of that briefing. The Minister can circumscribe the briefing, but it is virtually unknown for Ministers consistently to refuse briefings on matters of public importance before the Parliament in the form of legislation to members of parliament who are elected by the people. My colleague Senator Messner made a request to the Treasurer's office for a briefing on this Bill and he was refused. He wrote to the Treasurer on 29 April saying this:
I write to express my astonishment and deepest concern at being refused by your office a briefing by your departmental advisers on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1985.

It is not only my concern that the bill contains very complex provisions in respect of negative gearing but also introduces very extensive changes to the power of the Taxation Commissioner in connection with the new system of self-assessment of taxpayers. These are not inconsiderable issues which require detailed examination of legislation with your officers.
That is perfectly sensible. He goes on to say:
I have never been refused a briefing by any of your colleagues before. Furthermore, I have never known my colleagues in government to refuse your Party in Opposition a briefing on our legislation.

I have checked with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to see whether he, as the Treasurer in the previous Government, had refused briefings to the then Opposition on tax Bills or any other matter and he tells me that he did not. Senator Messner continued:

I view refusal of my request as gross negligence on your part to fully inform me, as shadow Minister for Finance and Taxation, with responsibility for the passage of this legislation through the Senate on behalf of the Opposition, of the full ramifications for the Australian taxpayer.
Senator Messner received a letter back from the Treasurer which stated:
I refer to your letter of 29 April-
and so on-
I have also received a request for briefings from Mr Aldred-
who, incidentally, is the honourable member for Bruce and Chairman of the Opposition Treasury Committee-

and enclose a copy of my response to him. As you will observe, there has been no `gross negligence' on my part to provide information-the offer to you to answer any question in writing stands. It is not for you to dictate the means in which such information is provided.
What did the Treasurer say to the honourable member for Bruce? He said:

The request by Senator Messner referred to in your letter was made to my office last week and referred to the negative gearing measure in particular. My office advised Senator Messner that any question on any tax measure introduced by the Government would be received and answered in writing. I reaffirm that if any Member or Senator has a question on tax matters before the Parliament, a prompt written response will be provided.
As far as briefings are concerned, I mention that my officers have not previously provided briefings to Opposition members on legislation.
That is nonsense; not since he has been Treasurer, of course. He continued:

In considering this matter, I must take into account the extraordinary work pressure now placed on Tax and Treasury officers who have a huge workload of Tax Reform work. I must also take into account the extremely irresponsible policy of outright opposition to tax reform measures announced by the Opposition, and hence the priority to be given to diverting the work undertaken by public servants in meeting their statutory functions to the needs of your political Party. This consideration is made all the more important now that you confirm that one briefing is not enough-you seek them for your Committee as well, and further demand could arise from other Parties. Finally, I draw attention to the decision of your Party to refuse to attend the National Tax Summit and broadly to be non-cooperative in the whole Tax Reform exercise.
I therefore must confirm that I am unable to release public servants for the various `briefing sessions' you may seek on the tax reform measures.

He then goes on to say that they might be available for other purposes. Quite honestly, this is almost a matter of parliamentary privilege. If the Treasurer were not a member of this Parliament, he would be up before the Parliament on a matter of privilege. He is just not saying that the Opposition cannot do this; he is talking about any private member. I wonder whether the Australian Democrats would get the same response from the Treasurer?

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Caucus have a briefing?

—My colleague, the honourable member for Mitchell, asks whether the Caucus had a briefing. All I can say is that this kind of arrogance will have its own reward as people realise what these measures are like. The first of those measures to which I wish to refer is negative gearing. The Government has a history of attacking home owners and home renters. One of the main promises that the Government made in its 1983 election policy speech was that it would give a high priority to home ownership. Unfortunately, the Government has gone in the opposite direction. It has a deliberate high interest rate policy under which interest rates rose during 1985, contrary to the promises made in the 1984 election. This high interest rate policy has resulted in an appalling cost on home purchasers, existing home owners and renters in the private market. As I said, interest rates rose substantially during 1985. In November last year, because of a further fall in the value of the dollar, the Government, as a deliberate act of policy, jacked up interest rates to their highest levels since the recession of the early 1930s.

SPEECH.PARA: The average cost of cocktail or building society loans went up to over 15 per cent, which is an enormous rate of interest for a home owner to have to pay. There was also a drying up of finance from savings banks and a severe downturn in the building industry. Of course, there was real pressure on low income earners who find it harder to meet the necessary requirements for a loan; they are the ones who find it harder to pay the increased interest charges. If there was a problem in getting low income earners into their own accommodation, clearly there was extra pressure on private rental accommodation and State housing commissions. Much of the rental accommodation has to be provided by the private sector, and that is proper.

On top of this incredible squeeze on the housing industry and on top of the squeeze that has already been put on the rental industry because of the incapacity of people to buy their own homes, we suffered two further major blows which, again, were deliberate acts of public policy. The first of these was the announcement on 17 July of the negative gearing proposals which are the subject of this legislation. The second deadly blow was the capital gains tax announced on 19 September last year which was, of course, quite contrary to a firm promise that was given by the Prime Minister in the 1983 election campaign when he committed the Australian Labor Party not to introduce a capital gains tax. I do not believe that the Government understands yet the combined effect of its high interest rate policies, its capital gains tax and its negative gearing proposals on the housing industry and particularly on the poorest families who rely on that industry to provide accommodation, either through home purchase or through rental. The combination of the capital gains tax and the removal of the negative gearing provisions is resulting in a drying up of new rental accommodation and it has forced up rents. Private sector approvals for new residential buildings have declined by 23.2 per cent since July 1985. Approvals since February have been at their lowest level since July 1983, which is still towards the end of the recession. Private sector approvals for home units, which make up the bulk of new private rental accommodation, were down 37.7 per cent.

The removal of the negative gearing provisions and the imposition of the capital gains tax has reduced the effect on investment properties, forcing owners to push rents up. Of course, a lot of people will not go into this area in the first place. The New South Wales Premier added to the confusion by threatening to control rents, resulting in a further exit from this market. These provisions, in simple terms, say that if one's interest costs on a rental property exceed the net rental income that one receives from the property exceed the net rental income that one receives from the property, insofar as those interest costs exceed the net rental income, they will no longer be deductible in the hands of the taxpayer. I will not go into the complexities of this, but that is the simple proposition. The opposition opposes this measure. It will be voting against this measure at the Committee stage; it will be voting against it in the Senate.

Let me go on to the other major area of concern in this legislation. I must say that it really is an outrage for debate on this legislation to be gagged and limited to a relatively short period. Of course, a number of measures have been put into this single package and I have only half an hour in which to deal with quite complex legislation. Because I am restricted in what I can say, I will be relying on my colleagues to make various other remarks. The present rules on amendment of assessment of taxation are as follows: Firstly, if a taxpayer has not made a full and true disclosure of all material facts necessary to make an assessment and any tax has been avoided and the Commissioner considers the avoidance to be due to fraud or evasion, he may amend the assessment at any time by making such alterations or additions as he considers necessary to correct an error in calculation or a mistake of fact or to prevent the avoidance of tax. Even where there has been an avoidance of tax due to fraud or evasion, the Commissioner's power to amend, although unlimited in time, is limited in extent. It is not a general power of amendment. He could not, for example, amend an assessment to reflect a changed interpretation of the law, but is limited to corrections or errors of calculation and mistakes of fact and prevention of the loss of revenue through tax avoidance.

Second, when there has been avoidance of tax not due to fraud or evasion, an amended assessment increasing liability can be validly made to correct an error of calculation or mistake of fact or to prevent the tax being avoided at any time within six years from the due date of the payment of tax under the assessment, the subject of amendment. However, as in the case of avoidance through fraud or evasion, no amendment increasing liability can be made unless at the time of its making there has not been full and true disclosure of all the material facts necessary for the taxpayer's proper assessment. Thirdly, where a full and true disclosure of all the material facts necessary for his assessment has been made by the taxpayer at any time before an assessment, original or amended, is issued to him, any subsequent amended assessment increasing his liability is competent only if it is made to correct an error in calculation or mistake of fact or issues within three years from the due date for payment of tax under the original or previous amended assessment.

Fourthly, ordinarily an amendment reducing liability may be made only within three years of the due date for payment of the tax under the assessment being amended. Moreover, only an amendment by way of correction of an error in calculation or mistake of fact is permitted. In addition, the taxpayer may make application for an amendment in his assessment. Such an application would have to be made within three years from the due date for payment of the tax due under the assessment and any information necessary for deciding the application must be supplied to the Commissioner within that time. If these conditions are satisfied the Commissioner may amend the assessment at any time. The Commissioner's power to amend an assessment to reduce liability and, particularly, his power to amend on the taxpayer's application, is discretionary, not mandatory. There is no power to amend reducing liability to correct a mistake of law as such.

The proposed changes basically are that within the time frames I have already mentioned, the Commissioner is to have the power to amend an assessment for any reason, including the correction of an error of law. Therefore, under this new proposal taxpayers are asked to make their own assessments. The return goes to the Taxation Office where it is not given the full scrutiny it is currently given. The return is given an assessment which has some binding significance for the taxpayer but this matter could float on for some time until, under the new auditing procedures of the Taxation Office, there might be a change in the situation for the taxpayer.

We have had discussions with leading tax practitioners around Australia and with representatives of taxpayer bodies. Considerable disquiet has been expressed at the extension of powers of the Commissioner. Most of this criticism concerns the lack of certainty that will result from not knowing, even if a full and true disclosure has been made in the return, the taxpayer's final tax liability. A fundamental aspect of our assessment procedure has been that if a full and true disclosure has been made no amendment to increase the tax liability can be made to reflect a changed interpretation of the law; it can be done only to create an error of calculation or mistake of fact. It appears that the changes could empower the Commissioner to amend assessments to increase a tax liability due to a change in interpretation of the law. In other words, we really will not know where we stand.

A number of other comments were made which I have not time to go into. However, I will summarise the four concerns which emerge from the introduction of this self-assessment system along the lines being proposed. First, I refer to the favoured position of the Taxation Commissioner in respect of interest for overpayment or underpayment of tax. In other words, in this situation if a person receives interest paid by the Commissioner because the Commissioner owes him money he pays tax on that interest. However, if the person has to pay interest on money which he owes the Taxation Commissioner he cannot deduct it. It is the usual thing of `heads I win, tails you lose' as far as the Commissioner of Taxation is concerned.

The second concerns the exclusion of an option for taxpayers to opt out of the self-assessment procedure in favour of scrutiny by the Commissioner where the taxpayer is uncertain about his assessment. In other words, there is no option for a taxpayer who would prefer to have a definite situation. He could float on for ages waiting for an audit. The third concern is the power of the Commissioner to reopen assessments following changes in the law. Fourth, while the Commissioner has power to reopen a case to increase tax liability the reopening of a case at the taxpayer's request to decrease the liability is at the Commissioner's discretion. The Commissioner already has very considerable powers and the provision of additional powers should be very seriously questioned.

I thought that to give some indication of the flavour of the reception to this taxation proposal out in the market place I would quote from a letter by Mr Robin Speed in the Australian Financial Review a couple of days ago. The letter is headed: `Justice needed on tax returns'. It gives an indication of the flavour of the concern out in the community of this and other measures. He said:
Sir, 300 years ago Daniel Defoe wrote that there was nothing as certain as death and taxes. Today, there is nothing as uncertain as taxes.
Never before have the tax laws been so complex or uncertain of application. I venture to suggest that there is no-one in or outside the Tax Department who understands the present Income Tax Act.
With the proposed introduction of capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax and imputation tax a gaggle of experts will be needed to answer a tax question.

It is therefore ironic for the Government at this time to introduce a self-assessment system which places the responsibility on taxpayers to know the tax laws. The system will first operate for the 1985-86 year. It involves prima face acceptance by the Tax Department of a taxpayer's return of income.
By and large it will rely on the honesty of taxpayers and random checks and investigations by the department to catch the dishonest taxpayer.
The tax laws are not black and white. What they mean today may not be what they mean tomorrow. On many points QCs, Supreme, Federal and High Court judges disagree among themselves.
If they have grave difficulty in working out the meaning of the tax laws, 99 per cent of Australians have no chance.
For self-assessment to be just to individual taxpayers and fair to taxpayers as a whole, certain safeguards and provisions must exist. These include:
A presumption that a taxpayer is innocent until the contrary is proved, an impartial review of all decisions by the department, and encouragement to make a full disclosure.
Removal of the suspicion of male fides-
that is bad faith-
and the temptation for blackmail or corruption inherent in the existing powers to impose 200 per cent penalties or remit penalties which could bankrupt a business or a family.
